The pact includes two key components: the 'Global Digital Compact'—the first comprehensive global framework for digital governance and cooperation—and the 'Declaration on Future Generations', which safeguards the rights and well-being of people yet to be born. The document commits nations to promoting sustainable development, peace and security, digital equity, innovation, and global governance reforms. The pact is rooted in human rights, gender equality, and multilateral cooperation, signaling a renewed vision for global progress.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What major geographic feature is formed at Khartoum, Sudan?
options: The formation of the Nile River by the confluence of the White and Blue Nile
The origin of the Congo River
The highest elevation point in North Africa
The source of the Red Sea
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: Sudan, located in Northeast Africa, plays a vital role in the Nile River system. In its capital, Khartoum, the White Nile (which originates from Lake Victoria in Uganda) and the Blue Nile (which flows from Lake Tana in Ethiopia) converge to form the main Nile River. This confluence is not just a geographical landmark but also critical for agriculture, water supply, and political cooperation among Nile Basin countries. Sudan’s location between Sub-Saharan Africa and the Middle East also makes it a region of geopolitical importance. Clashes in areas like Kordofan further highlight the country’s internal instability.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What change has been introduced in the Consumer Price Index for Agricultural and Rural Labourers (CPI-AL & RL)?
options: The index is now calculated using artificial intelligence
It now excludes non-agricultural rural occupations
The Labour Bureau no longer compiles the index
The base year has been updated to 2019=100 from 1986-87=100
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: The Consumer Price Index for Agricultural Labourers (CPI-AL) and Rural Labourers (CPI-RL) tracks the cost of living for rural workers by measuring changes in prices of essential goods and services. Compiled by the Labour Bureau under the Ministry of Labour and Employment, it is a crucial indicator for determining minimum wages and social benefits. The base year for this index has now been updated from 1986–87 to 2019=100 to reflect current consumption patterns and price structures. This revision ensures better accuracy in wage policy and rural welfare schemes, aligning data with modern economic realities.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: Why is India's request to co-produce Javelin ATGMs with the United States significant?
options: It allows India to export the Javelin missile system to NATO countries
It enhances India's indigenous defence manufacturing under Make in India
It reduces the cost of importing tanks from the US
It replaces the Pinaka missile system for air-to-air combat
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: India has submitted a formal request to the United States for the co-production of Javelin Anti-Tank Guided Missiles (ATGMs) under the 'Make in India' initiative. Javelin is a premier fire-and-forget, man-portable, medium-range anti-tank missile system that guides itself to the target after launch. Co-producing such a sophisticated system would reduce dependency on imports, strengthen India's defence-industrial base, and align with the Atmanirbhar Bharat (self-reliant India) mission.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What is the Netra MkII, recently approved by the Indian government?
options: An Indian missile system designed for mountain warfare
A communication satellite under ISRO’s NavIC program
An advanced airborne early warning and control system based on Airbus A321
A stealth drone designed for cross-border surveillance
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: Netra MkII is India's next-generation Airborne Early Warning and Control System (AEW&C), approved for development on the Airbus A321 aircraft. This flying command center is equipped with Active Electronically Scanned Array (AESA) radars and mission control systems, enabling it to detect, monitor, and track threats over vast distances. It significantly enhances India's airspace surveillance, early warning, and tactical control capabilities, especially in critical border areas.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What is the objective of the NSCSTI 2.0 framework unveiled recently?
options: To set up private training schools for UPSC aspirants
To regulate training of judicial officers in India
To recruit AI-based tutors for government training academies
To build future-ready civil services training institutes
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: The National Standards for Civil Service Training Institutes 2.0 (NSCSTI 2.0) was launched by the Capacity Building Commission (CBC) to modernize civil services training institutes in India. The framework aims to make them future-ready through streamlined evaluation metrics, inclusive design, and digital readiness for hybrid learning. The CBC, established in 2021, implements Mission Karmayogi—the government’s capacity-building initiative to transform Indian bureaucracy into a more agile, tech-savvy, and citizen-centric workforce.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: Which of the following statements about the International Criminal Court (ICC) is correct?
options: India was one of the founding members of the ICC
The ICC only tries disputes between nations
The ICC investigates serious crimes like genocide and crimes against humanity
Its headquarters is located in Geneva, Switzerland
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: The International Criminal Court (ICC), headquartered in The Hague, Netherlands, is the first permanent international tribunal for prosecuting individuals accused of grave crimes like genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity, and aggression. It was established under the Rome Statute adopted in 1998, which came into force in 2002. Recently, Ukraine became the 125th State Party to the Rome Statute. India, however, is not a signatory to the Statute due to concerns related to sovereignty and jurisdiction.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What is the purpose of the newly notified Offshore Areas Mineral (Development and Regulation) Rules, 2024?
options: To regulate exploration and mining of atomic minerals like uranium and thorium in offshore areas
To ban all mineral exploration in coastal areas
To allow unrestricted mining of beach sand minerals
To permit private foreign companies to mine in forest areas
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: The Offshore Areas Mineral (Development and Regulation) Rules, 2024, were notified to regulate the exploration and mining of atomic minerals like uranium and thorium in India’s offshore regions. These rules apply only if the concentration of atomic minerals exceeds a specified threshold. Government-nominated entities may be granted exploration licences or production leases, and foreign entities must obtain prior approval. Uranium reserves in India are mostly in Jharkhand, Andhra Pradesh, and Rajasthan, with Jaduguda being India’s first commercial uranium mine. India has limited uranium but rich thorium deposits—especially monazite-bearing sands in Kerala and Odisha.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What is the main goal of Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC)?
options: To use quantum entanglement for secure communication
To develop encryption compatible only with quantum computers
To completely replace classical cryptographic systems with quantum-only methods
To create encryption methods that can withstand quantum attacks while remaining compatible with classical systems
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) is designed to develop encryption techniques that are secure against potential quantum computer-based attacks, while still working on today's classical computers. Quantum computers pose a threat to current cryptographic systems like RSA and ECC because of their ability to solve complex problems—such as integer factorization—much faster using algorithms like Shor's. In response, countries are racing to future-proof digital infrastructure. The U.S. NIST has announced four standardized PQC algorithms in 2023, while India, under the Ministry of Electronics and IT, is investing in PQC as part of the National Mission on Quantum Technologies and the IndiaAI roadmap. This ensures national resilience against quantum-era cyber threats across sectors like defense, Aadhaar, banking, and telecom.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: Why are 'Harvest Now, Decrypt Later' (HNDL) attacks considered a major cybersecurity threat?
options: They use AI to generate future passwords
They exploit vulnerabilities in classical encryption using current supercomputers
They intercept and store encrypted data today to decrypt it in the future using quantum computing
They are already used by military hackers to access state secrets
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: HNDL (Harvest Now, Decrypt Later) attacks are a critical threat model in modern cybersecurity. In this model, adversaries collect encrypted data such as defense communication, financial transactions, or health records today, with the aim of decrypting them in the future once quantum computers become capable. This is especially alarming for long-retention data like military or diplomatic archives. Globally, intelligence reports suggest that countries like China and the U.S. are building quantum-ready data centers for this purpose. In India, where sensitive digital systems like Aadhaar, CoWIN, and national defense communication are active, preparation against such threats is vital. The Indian Cyber Coordination Centre (I4C) and CERT-In have begun issuing advisories and planning transitions to quantum-resilient systems.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What role do grassroots NGOs and civil society organisations play in cyber awareness?
options: They help educate vulnerable communities about basic digital hygiene and threats
They provide direct cyber protection services to critical infrastructure
They are responsible for drafting national cybersecurity policies
They audit government websites for cyber risks
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: NGOs and civil society organisations (CSOs) are crucial in bridging the 'last-mile gap' in India’s digital landscape. While the government sets national policy, these groups work at the community level to raise awareness about cyber hygiene—like avoiding phishing links, using strong passwords, recognizing fake apps, etc. In villages and underserved areas connected via BharatNet or using digital banking, these users are highly vulnerable to cyber fraud. The Ministry of Electronics and IT's 'Information Security Education and Awareness (ISEA)' program and the 'Cyber Surakshit Bharat' campaign actively collaborate with such groups to spread digital literacy. For instance, in 2023, campaigns with NGOs helped train rural women in Rajasthan and Jharkhand on secure smartphone usage. This bottom-up approach strengthens national cyber resilience by turning individuals into the first line of defense.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: Why is quantum computing considered a threat to classical encryption methods?
options: Because it works faster than classical computers
Because it uses random number generation for brute-force attacks
Because it can factor large prime numbers exponentially faster, breaking RSA and ECC encryption
Because it manipulates encrypted data using artificial intelligence
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: Quantum computers leverage quantum mechanics to perform certain operations exponentially faster than classical computers. One of the most famous quantum algorithms—Shor’s Algorithm—can factor large prime numbers efficiently, breaking the backbone of RSA encryption. Similarly, Grover’s Algorithm can reduce brute-force search time. As a result, widely used public-key cryptographic systems (like those used in digital signatures, secure browsing, and ATM transactions) become insecure. Governments worldwide, including India, are now investing heavily in quantum-safe cryptography. The Indian Army and DRDO are already testing secure quantum communication between defense centers. If India doesn’t act promptly, critical systems like Aadhaar, health records, and digital banking could be exposed to quantum threats in the near future.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: How is India preparing to deal with cybersecurity challenges from emerging quantum technologies?
options: By creating a National Data Protection Force
By launching a Digital India Quantum Secure campaign
By banning quantum devices from critical infrastructure
By funding research and applications under the National Mission on Quantum Technologies & Applications (NMQTA)
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: India’s preparation against quantum-era cybersecurity threats is centered around the ₹8,000 crore National Mission on Quantum Technologies & Applications (NMQTA), launched in 2020 under the Department of Science and Technology. It funds research in quantum communication, quantum cryptography, post-quantum algorithms, and the development of quantum computers. Institutes like IIT Madras, IISER Pune, and DRDO labs are conducting pilot projects for quantum key distribution (QKD), including trials on quantum-secure communication between defense and government nodes. Additionally, India’s Semiconductor Mission and collaborations in international forums like the Quad Critical and Emerging Technologies Working Group are integrating quantum cybersecurity into India's strategic tech development. This is essential for protecting India's digital sovereignty in sectors like fintech, digital health, e-governance, and national defense.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What is the main objective of the GENIUS Act introduced in the United States?
options: To establish a regulatory framework for stablecoins
To promote Bitcoin mining in the U.S.
To regulate all cryptocurrencies under a single authority
To ban the use of non-government-issued cryptocurrencies
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: The GENIUS (Guaranteeing Effective National Investment in Unifying Stablecoins) Act is a recent legislative proposal in the U.S. aimed at creating a clear regulatory framework for stablecoins, a special type of cryptocurrency whose value is pegged to stable assets like the U.S. dollar. Stablecoins are gaining popularity due to their reduced price volatility compared to traditional cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. The Act proposes that only regulated entities, such as insured banks or credit unions, be allowed to issue stablecoins, ensuring consumer protection and preventing misuse for illegal activities. It is part of a broader global effort to regulate the growing digital finance space while maintaining monetary stability.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: Why have stablecoins gained popularity over other cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin?
options: They are completely decentralized
They are backed by underlying assets, making their value more stable
They offer higher returns on investment
They are issued by central banks globally
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: Stablecoins are considered more reliable than volatile cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin because they are usually pegged to real-world assets such as the U.S. dollar or gold. This linkage keeps their value relatively constant, making them ideal for transactions, remittances, and as a digital store of value. For example, USDT (Tether) and USDC (USD Coin) are widely used stablecoins. Unlike Bitcoin, which can fluctuate by hundreds of dollars in a single day, stablecoins maintain parity with their pegged value. This has made them attractive for use in cross-border payments, DeFi (Decentralized Finance), and e-commerce, especially in economies with unstable local currencies.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What legal steps has India taken regarding Virtual Digital Assets (VDAs)?
options: India has made cryptocurrency fully legal and regulated by SEBI
India banned all forms of crypto transactions
India imposed a 30% tax on capital gains from VDAs and brought them under PMLA
India has declared VDAs as legal tender
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: India has taken cautious but firm steps to manage the rise of Virtual Digital Assets (VDAs), including cryptocurrencies. In the 2022 Union Budget, the government imposed a flat 30% tax on profits earned from trading VDAs. Additionally, a 1% TDS (Tax Deducted at Source) is levied on every crypto transaction above a certain threshold. More recently, under the 2023 update to the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA), cryptocurrency exchanges and platforms were brought under its ambit. This means these platforms must now follow strict Know Your Customer (KYC) norms and report suspicious transactions, similar to banks and financial institutions. These measures aim to prevent the misuse of crypto for money laundering or terror financing while indirectly acknowledging its growing role in the financial ecosystem.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: What is the method used in 'Digital Arrest' scams?
options: Intimidating victims with fake threats of legal action to extort money
Hacking into online banking systems
Using malware to lock phones
Physically intercepting people for ransom
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: Digital arrest scams are a dangerous form of cybercrime where fraudsters impersonate police officers, government officials, or even foreign embassy staff. Victims receive phone calls or video calls accusing them of crimes like money laundering, drug trafficking, or financial fraud. The scammers then threaten 'digital arrest'—meaning the victim is told not to leave their home or interact with anyone. Under pressure and fear, the victim is coerced into transferring large sums of money to fake government accounts for 'legal clearance'. This type of fraud exploits fear, lack of awareness, and the increasing dependence on digital communication. Recent cases in India, especially in metro cities, have seen rising reports of such scams.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.questionText: Which initiatives have been taken by the Indian government to combat cyber frauds like digital arrest?
options: Enacting the Cyber Police Act
Establishing CERT-IN as the only anti-cybercrime unit
Creating coordination platforms like I4C, CFMC, and Samanvaya, and launching tools like Report and Check Suspect
Banning social media platforms suspected of scams
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 20,.explanation: The Government of India has recognized the alarming rise in cyber frauds such as digital arrest, UPI frauds, and phishing scams. In response, the Indian Cyber Crime Coordination Centre (I4C) was established under the Ministry of Home Affairs to serve as a nodal agency. Alongside, platforms like CFMC (Citizen Financial Cyber Fraud Reporting and Management System) have been set up for rapid coordination between banks, telecom companies, and police. The 'Samanvaya' portal further enhances interstate police coordination in cyber cases. Citizens can also use 'Report and Check Suspect' features on the portal cybercrime.gov.in to verify unknown callers or messages. These combined efforts aim to create a fast-response ecosystem to protect people and disrupt cybercrime networks effectively.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Why did India send 3 lakh doses of the Measles-Rubella vaccine to Bolivia?
options: To support Bolivia's routine immunization campaign
To help Bolivia combat a COVID-19 resurgence
As a goodwill gesture during Bolivia's national elections
To aid Bolivia amid a measles-rubella outbreak
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: India sent 3 lakh doses of the Measles-Rubella vaccine to Bolivia in response to a recent outbreak in the country. The move highlights India's proactive role in global health diplomacy and South-South cooperation.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Which of the following is true about the geographical features of Bolivia?
options: Bolivia borders only three countries and has a coastline
Lake Titicaca lies entirely within Bolivian territory
Bolivia is landlocked and bordered by five South American countries
The country is dominated by the Amazon rainforest
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: Bolivia is a landlocked country in west-central South America. It is bordered by Brazil to the north and east, Paraguay and Argentina to the south, Chile to the southwest, and Peru to the northwest. The Andes mountain ranges dominate its topography, and Lake Titicaca lies on its border with Peru.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What is the Urban Wind Stilling Effect responsible for in North India?
options: Creating Urban Aerosol Clean Islands by slowing dust entry
Generating stronger monsoon winds in cities
Increasing aerosol pollution in urban areas
Raising the temperature of rural zones
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The Urban Wind Stilling Effect, caused by urban structures weakening surface winds, creates invisible barriers that limit the movement of long-range dust and pollutants. This has led to the formation of 'Urban Aerosol Clean Islands' in 43% of cities in north and northwest Indo-Gangetic Plain.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Why is CERN's observation of CP violation in baryons considered a breakthrough?
options: It confirms the equal presence of matter and antimatter in the universe
It supports the idea of an expanding universe
It explains the behavior of quantum entanglement
It provides insight into the matter–antimatter asymmetry in the universe
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The observation of CP violation in baryons by CERN scientists is a significant milestone in understanding the matter–antimatter asymmetry in the universe. Despite the Big Bang theory predicting equal quantities of matter and antimatter, the universe is largely matter-dominated, and CP violation helps explain this imbalance.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What makes the Akash Prime missile system suitable for deployment in Ladakh?
options: It can function in cold, high-altitude, low-oxygen environments
It has underwater attack capabilities
It operates on satellite-guided precision targeting
It is designed for low-altitude tropical conditions
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: Akash Prime is a robust variant of the Akash Surface-to-Air Missile system, developed by DRDO. It is specially designed to operate in extreme weather conditions, such as the cold, high-altitude, low-oxygen environment of Ladakh, where it recently destroyed two aerial targets.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: MoSPI has urged the integration of the 8th Economic Census with which of the following national exercises?
options: National Family Health Survey (NFHS)
16th Population Census
All India Financial Survey
Socio-Economic and Caste Census
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI) has suggested integrating the groundwork of the 8th Economic Census with the 16th Population Census. The goal is to optimize resources and enhance the comprehensiveness of data. While the Economic Census focuses on all entrepreneurial units engaged in economic activities, the Population Census collects demographic data—together, they help build a stronger data foundation for policy-making.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What is the objective of the PM VIKAS scheme launched by the Ministry of Minority Affairs?
options: Promotion of rural crafts through cooperatives
Financial literacy and inclusion for urban poor
Upliftment of minorities through skill development and education
Urban housing for backward classes
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: PM VIKAS (Pradhan Mantri Virasat Ka Samvardhan) is a central sector scheme aimed at improving the livelihoods of minority communities. It merges five earlier schemes and focuses on skilling, leadership development among women, entrepreneurship, and education. The scheme especially targets traditional artisans and craftspeople to preserve cultural heritage while enhancing income generation.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: SIMBEX 2025, where the Indian Navy is set to participate, is a maritime exercise held with which country?
options: Indonesia
Japan
Australia
Singapore
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: SIMBEX stands for 'Singapore-India Maritime Bilateral Exercise.' It is one of the longest continuous bilateral naval exercises India has conducted with any country since 1994. It strengthens naval cooperation and enhances interoperability in maritime operations such as anti-submarine warfare, maritime security, and communication drills.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Which institution publishes the 'State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World' (SOFI) report?
options: UN Environment Programme
World Health Organization
UNESCO
Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO)
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The SOFI report is published annually by FAO in collaboration with other UN agencies like IFAD, UNICEF, WFP, and WHO. It tracks progress on global hunger, food insecurity, and malnutrition. The 2024 edition revealed that over 735 million people were chronically undernourished globally, highlighting ongoing challenges despite targeted programs and efforts.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Which Indian city has recently been recognized with the title of ‘World Book Capital’ by UNESCO?
options: Delhi
Mumbai
Hyderabad
Kolkata
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: Hyderabad has been selected as UNESCO's World Book Capital for its vibrant literary culture and strong publishing ecosystem. The designation highlights the city's commitment to promoting books, reading, libraries, and literacy through inclusive public events. The title is given annually to a city that demonstrates innovative programs for advancing reading and education.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What is the purpose of the directions issued by CARA to the State Adoption Resource Agencies (SARAs)?
options: To reinforce psychosocial support for all stakeholders involved in child adoption
To introduce financial incentives for adoptive parents
To centralize adoption processes under one national agency
To remove the need for counselling during the adoption process
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The Central Adoption Resource Authority (CARA) issued directions to SARAs to reinforce the psychosocial support framework for prospective adoptive parents, adopted children, and biological parents. This is aligned with the Juvenile Justice Act (amended 2021) and the Adoption Regulations, 2022, and emphasizes the need for qualified counsellors at both state and district levels.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Under which legislative framework does CARA function for regulating adoption in India?
options: Child Welfare and Rehabilitation Act
Hindu Succession Act
Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act
National Child Rights Protection Act
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: CARA (Central Adoption Resource Authority) functions under the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 (amended 2021). It is the nodal body regulating domestic and intercountry adoptions in India, ensuring that they are ethical and legally sound.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What is the purpose of the Hague Convention of 1993 in the context of adoption?
options: To promote inter-religious adoptions
To speed up the domestic adoption process
To replace national adoption laws with a global framework
To ensure ethical and transparent international adoptions
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The Hague Convention on Protection of Children and Cooperation in Respect of Intercountry Adoption (1993) is an international treaty that aims to prevent child trafficking and ensure that intercountry adoptions are conducted legally, ethically, and transparently.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What is the major concern of Telangana regarding the Polavaram Banakacherla Link Project (PBLP)?
options: Violation of the water-sharing agreement under the AP Reorganisation Act, 2014
Environmental impact on the Western Ghats
Construction delays caused by lack of funds
Opposition from the central government
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: Telangana has raised objections against the Polavaram Banakacherla Link Project, claiming that Andhra Pradesh is violating the inter-state water-sharing agreement stipulated in the AP Reorganisation Act, 2014. This dispute led the Centre to form a high-level committee to look into the issue.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Which constitutional provision allows the formation of tribunals for resolving inter-state river water disputes?
options: Article 262 of the Constitution
Article 370 of the Constitution
Article 356 of the Constitution
Article 243 of the Constitution
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: Article 262 empowers Parliament to make laws for adjudicating disputes related to inter-state rivers. The Inter-State River Water Disputes Act, 1956, enacted under this article, provides for tribunals to handle such cases. Additionally, courts are barred from jurisdiction once a tribunal is set up.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What does the Global Wetland Outlook 2025 reveal about the current state of global wetlands?
options: Wetlands have remained stable in coverage since 1970
Only marine wetlands have seen significant degradation
22% of global wetlands have been lost since 1970
Wetlands are primarily found in high-income countries
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: According to the Global Wetland Outlook 2025, the world has lost 22% of its wetlands since 1970. Wetlands, including inland freshwater and coastal types, cover 1,800 million hectares globally. The report highlights that wetland degradation is especially severe in lower-income countries, and Africa's wetlands are among the most degraded.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Which of the following best describes the Ramsar Convention's strategic alignment?
options: It focuses solely on economic development through tourism
It aligns with the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework targets
It is limited to inland wetlands in Europe
It promotes industrial use of wetlands
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The Ramsar Convention's strategic goals are in line with the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework (KM-GBF) targets. This alignment strengthens the global approach to wetland conservation, linking it with biodiversity protection and sustainable development goals.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Which initiative is restoring over 140 wetlands critical for migratory birds and nearly 200 million people?
options: Seychelles Blue Bond Project
Global Ramsar Rescue Program
Regional Flyway Initiative
Clean Waters Global Taskforce
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The Regional Flyway Initiative is a $3 billion partnership across Asia that is working to restore more than 140 wetlands important for migratory birds and the livelihoods of about 200 million people. It stands as one of the best case studies in wetland restoration and cooperation.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: Which cities entered the new 'Super Swachh League' category in Swachh Survekshan 2024-25?
options: Mumbai, Delhi, and Kolkata
Chennai, Hyderabad, and Jaipur
Indore, Surat, and Navi Mumbai
Bangalore, Pune, and Lucknow
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: In the Swachh Survekshan 2024-25, the new category ‘Super Swachh League’ was introduced to honor cities with consistently high performance. Indore, Surat, and Navi Mumbai were inducted into this elite group, recognizing their sustained efforts in urban cleanliness.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.questionText: What is the objective of the Accelerated Dumpsite Remediation Program launched during Swachh Survekshan 2024-25?
options: To expand dumpsites in urban areas
To import waste processing technology
To remediate legacy waste and boost scientific waste processing capacity
To centralize waste disposal in metropolitan cities
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 19,.explanation: The Accelerated Dumpsite Remediation Program is a special one-year initiative launched to tackle legacy waste issues. It aims to clear old waste dumps and enhance the scientific waste processing capacity of urban areas, forming a key component of Swachh Bharat Mission's next phase.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What triggered the recent violent clashes in Sweida, Syria?
options: Conflict between Kurdish forces and Syrian Army
Clashes between Sunni Bedouin tribal fighters and Druze militias
A civil war between Christians and Yazidis
An international airstrike on Syrian borders
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Sweida, located in southern Syria, has witnessed renewed tensions between local communities. In July 2025, violence broke out between Sunni Bedouin tribal fighters and Druze militias. The region, part of the Levant and bordered by Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, and Israel, has been impacted by the ongoing civil conflict in Syria. The Druze, a minority religious group, and Bedouin tribes have longstanding disputes over land, resources, and political control. These clashes highlight the fragility of local governance and the broader ethnic and sectarian challenges Syria continues to face.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What makes Iceland particularly prone to earthquake swarms?
options: It sits on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge and over a mantle plume
It is located on the Pacific Ring of Fire
It experiences extreme weather fluctuations
It lies in a high-pressure tectonic basin
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Iceland is one of the most geologically active regions in the world. It sits at the meeting point of the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates, known as the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. In addition to this tectonic boundary, Iceland is also situated over a mantle plume—a column of hot magma rising from deep within the Earth. This dual influence makes Iceland prone to volcanic activity and frequent earthquake swarms—sequences of many small earthquakes without a major main shock. These swarms can precede volcanic eruptions, such as the recent lava eruption from a massive fissure triggered by a swarm of quakes in 2025.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What key behaviour do Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) exhibit during their journey to Earth?
options: They continuously release heat until they fade
They change direction depending on solar winds
They initially release heat but later absorb and retain it
They become harmless before reaching Earth
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) are massive bursts of solar plasma and magnetic fields ejected from the Sun’s outer atmosphere, or corona. Astronomers recently discovered that CMEs exhibit a unique thermal behavior—initially, they release heat, but midway through their journey toward Earth, they begin to absorb and retain heat. This finding came after a powerful CME caused rare northern lights (auroras) in Ladakh in May 2024. Fast CMEs can reach Earth in 15–18 hours and cause geomagnetic storms that disrupt satellites, communication networks, and power grids. Studying this behavior is important for predicting space weather and protecting infrastructure.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What is the primary objective of Gujarat’s Tribal Genome Sequencing Project?
options: To study the linguistic traits of tribal populations
To enable AI-based surveillance of health trends
To map tribal biodiversity for conservation purposes
To identify genetic risks and enable precision healthcare
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Gujarat has launched India’s first Tribal Genome Sequencing Project aimed at improving healthcare for tribal populations. The initiative will sequence the genomes of 2,000 individuals from 17 tribal districts. By analyzing their genetic data, scientists hope to detect early signs of inherited diseases like sickle cell anaemia, thalassemia, and hereditary cancers. The project is implemented by the Gujarat Biotechnology Research Centre (GBRC) and marks a significant step toward personalized medicine. It seeks to address long-standing health disparities in tribal communities by offering precision treatments based on genetic risk factors.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What did the Supreme Court rule in the HUDA vs. Landowners case regarding the right to rehabilitation?
options: Rehabilitation is not a fundamental or constitutionally guaranteed right
Rehabilitation is a part of the right to life under Article 21
States are obligated to provide housing in all land acquisition cases
Rehabilitation must be ensured under all compensation schemes
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: In a significant judgment (Estate Officer, HUDA vs. landowners), the Supreme Court of India clarified that rehabilitation is not a fundamental right. Although Article 21 of the Constitution guarantees the right to life, the Court ruled that the loss of livelihood due to land acquisition does not automatically entitle affected persons to rehabilitation. Fair monetary compensation is constitutionally mandated, but offering alternative housing or employment lies outside the Court's jurisdiction unless explicitly provided by law. The Court reaffirmed earlier judgments like Amarjit Singh vs. State of Punjab (2010) and State of MP vs. Narmada Bachao Andolan (2011), which also emphasized this limitation.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: Which of the following Indian states are covered under the National GLOF Risk Mitigation Program (2021–2026)?
options: Sikkim, Manipur, Mizoram, Meghalaya
Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana
Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Sikkim, Assam
Uttarakhand, Sikkim, Himachal Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: The National Glacial Lake Outburst Flood (GLOF) Risk Mitigation Program (2021–2026) aims to monitor and reduce the risks posed by GLOFs. It is currently being implemented in four Himalayan states: Uttarakhand, Sikkim, Himachal Pradesh, and Arunachal Pradesh. These states are especially vulnerable due to the presence of numerous glacial lakes formed by melting glaciers. A GLOF occurs when these lakes suddenly release water, often due to a dam failure or seismic activity, which can cause catastrophic flooding downstream, as seen in the 2023 South Lhonak disaster in Sikkim.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What is the primary cause of most earthquakes and volcanic activity around the Pacific Ring of Fire?
options: Extreme weather conditions
Meteor impacts
Plate tectonics
Oceanic pressure variations
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: The Pacific Ring of Fire is a horseshoe-shaped zone around the Pacific Ocean known for its frequent earthquakes and active volcanoes. This area is seismically active due to the continuous movement of tectonic plates—massive slabs of the Earth's crust that shift and interact. These interactions cause earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and the formation of deep trenches like the Mariana Trench, the world’s deepest spot. Roughly 90% of the world’s earthquakes and 75% of all active volcanoes are located along this ring, including regions like Alaska, Japan, and Chile.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What is a major infrastructure-related issue affecting agricultural marketing in India, according to the Central Institute of Post-Harvest Engineering & Technology?
options: Shortage of seeds and fertilizers
Post-harvest losses due to inadequate storage and transport
Poor availability of digital services
Low soil productivity in rural areas
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: India suffers from significant post-harvest losses, amounting to ₹92,000 crore annually, largely due to inadequate cold storage, transportation, and warehousing infrastructure. This issue, identified by the Central Institute of Post-Harvest Engineering & Technology, affects the efficiency of agricultural marketing. Much of the farm produce gets spoiled before reaching the market. To tackle this, the government has launched schemes like the Agriculture Infrastructure Fund, e-NAM (National Agriculture Market), and promoted the formation of 10,000 Farmer Producer Organizations (FPOs) to improve market access and storage capacity for farmers.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What recent announcement was made by CSC e-Governance Services India Limited on the 10th anniversary of Digital India?
options: Launch of a national fiber optic network
Launch of India's first rural satellite mission
Direct benefit transfer of electricity bills in villages
Free AI training for 10 lakh individuals with focus on VLEs
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: As part of the 10-year celebration of Digital India, the government announced free Artificial Intelligence (AI) training for 10 lakh individuals, with priority given to Village Level Entrepreneurs (VLEs). These entrepreneurs operate Common Service Centers (CSCs)—rural digital hubs delivering government and financial services to citizens. Established in 2006 under MeitY, CSCs have expanded from 83,000 in 2014 to over 5.5 lakh centers, reaching about 90% of villages in India. They offer services like Aadhaar updates, passport applications, banking, and insurance, thereby driving digital inclusion in rural areas.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: How was ancient Buddhist heritage recently discovered in Haryana’s Yamuna Nagar district?
options: Using archaeological excavation only
With the help of satellite imagery
By chance during road construction
Using Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) technology
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Researchers from IIT Kanpur used Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) technology to detect ancient Buddhist stupas and buried structures in Yamuna Nagar, Haryana. GPR is a non-invasive, high-resolution geophysical method that uses electromagnetic waves to detect underground anomalies such as soil layers, water tables, and buried objects. GPR can reach depths of up to 10 meters and is increasingly being used in archaeology to uncover historical sites without disturbing the surface. This method helps preserve historical integrity while enabling detailed underground mapping.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What makes the Banni Grassland in Gujarat significant for the cheetah translocation project?
options: It is India's largest forest reserve.
It has high-altitude Himalayan grasslands suitable for snow leopards.
It is Asia’s largest tropical grassland with salt-tolerant vegetation.
It is a desert ecosystem surrounded by the Thar Desert.
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Banni Grassland in Gujarat’s Kutch district is Asia’s largest tropical grassland. It is a unique salt-tolerant grassland ecosystem, making it a suitable habitat for cheetahs under Project Cheetah.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: Which of the following is TRUE regarding Project Cheetah?
options: It is the first intercontinental translocation of a wild, large carnivore.
It involves relocating cheetahs from India to Africa.
It was launched in 2012 under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972.
It aims to conserve the Asiatic lion population in Gir Forest.
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Project Cheetah was launched in 2022 and is the world’s first intercontinental reintroduction of a wild, large carnivore. It aims to reintroduce African cheetahs into India, primarily in Kuno National Park.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What distinguishes the cheetah from other big cats such as lions, tigers, and leopards?
options: Cheetahs are stronger and more aggressive than other big cats.
Cheetahs are the only big cats that roar louder than lions.
Cheetahs cannot purr or make any vocal sounds.
Cheetahs do not roar and are the fastest land mammals.
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Unlike other big cats (lion, tiger, leopard, jaguar), cheetahs do not roar. They are also the fastest land mammals, capable of speeds up to 100 km/h.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What is the primary purpose of Mitochondrial Replacement Therapy (MRT)?
options: To replace a person’s brain mitochondria with robotic components.
To cure diseases by modifying nuclear DNA of both parents.
To replace faulty mitochondrial DNA in an embryo with healthy donor mitochondria.
To create identical clones using mitochondrial DNA only.
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: MRT is a technique that replaces defective mitochondrial DNA in a woman’s egg or embryo with healthy mitochondria from a donor. It prevents mitochondrial diseases which are passed maternally.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: Why are babies born through MRT sometimes referred to as 'Three-Parent Babies'?
options: Because three parents raise them.
Because they have three DNA types – nuclear DNA from two parents and mitochondrial DNA from a third donor.
Because they are genetically modified for three generations.
Because they are created using DNA from three siblings.
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: In MRT, the baby receives nuclear DNA from the mother and father, and healthy mitochondrial DNA from a female donor. Hence, the child has DNA from three genetic contributors.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: Which university became the first to open a campus in India under UGC’s 2023 regulations for Foreign Higher Educational Institutions?
options: University of Southampton
Deakin University
University of Wollongong
University of Oxford
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: The University of Southampton became the first global university to open a campus in India under the UGC’s 2023 regulations (Setting up and Operation of Campuses of Foreign Higher Educational Institutions in India). It opened its campus in Gurugram.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: Under the UGC’s 2023 regulation, what is the eligibility for foreign universities to establish campuses in India?
options: Must have 50 years of operational experience
Must be affiliated to Indian universities
Must conduct only online programs
Must be in top 500 global ranking or have exceptional expertise in a subject area
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Foreign universities eligible to establish campuses must rank among the top 500 globally in overall or subject-wise rankings or possess outstanding expertise in a particular subject area.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: What is the primary aim of the Prime Minister Dhan-Dhaanya Krishi Yojana (PMDDKY)?
options: To enhance agriculture and allied sectors in underperforming districts
To promote foreign university collaborations
To provide free education in rural areas
To modernize urban farming techniques
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: The PMDDKY is the first scheme focused exclusively on improving agriculture and allied sectors in underperforming districts, drawing inspiration from NITI Aayog’s Aspirational District Programme.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: Which of the following is not a challenge associated with setting up foreign campuses in India?
options: Cultural and operational differences
Collaborative research opportunities
Legal uncertainties over land and IP rights
Financial viability and affordability
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: Collaborative research and innovation is actually seen as a benefit of foreign institutions operating in India, whereas challenges include cultural adaptation, legal complexities, and financial sustainability.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.questionText: How many districts will the PMDDKY scheme target and over what period?
options: 100 districts over six years starting from 2025-26
112 districts over five years starting from 2022-23
50 districts over three years starting from 2023-24
150 districts over ten years starting from 2026
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 18,.explanation: The PMDDKY scheme will run for six years starting from 2025-26 and will focus on 100 underperforming districts in agriculture and allied sectors.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What is the main goal of the Corporate Average Fuel Efficiency (CAFE) norms?
options: To improve road safety through design regulations
To reduce vehicle production costs for manufacturers
To mitigate fuel consumption by lowering CO₂ emissions
To promote diesel over petrol usage in vehicles
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: CAFE norms aim to improve average fuel efficiency and reduce CO₂ emissions of vehicles sold in India, thereby reducing oil dependency and pollution. These standards are calculated based on the average fuel consumption of all passenger vehicles sold annually.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: Who is eligible for the Prime Minister Professorships under the Anusandhan National Research Foundation (ANRF)?
options: Only serving IIT professors from India
All government employees in the education sector
International diplomats involved in science diplomacy
Retired or superannuated scientists including NRIs and OCIs
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: The PM Professorships are open to eminent retired scientists including NRIs, PIOs, and OCIs. The scheme aims to leverage their expertise to boost scientific research in qualified state universities under the ANRF’s PAIR program.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: Which radiation types can newer portable Radiation Monitoring Systems (RMS) detect?
options: Only gamma radiation
Alpha, beta, and gamma radiation
Only alpha and beta radiation
None of the above
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: Unlike older Geiger counters that mainly detect gamma radiation, newer portable RMS devices can detect alpha, beta, and gamma radiation. These are used in nuclear plants, hospitals, and national security operations.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: Which countries are members of the BIMSTEC group?
options: India, China, Nepal, Maldives, and Bhutan
Indonesia, Malaysia, India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka
India, Singapore, Vietnam, Bangladesh, and Maldives
Bangladesh, India, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand, Nepal, and Bhutan
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: BIMSTEC comprises seven member countries: Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, and Thailand. It aims to foster technical and economic cooperation in the Bay of Bengal region.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What is significant about the GW231123 gravitational wave event?
options: It was the first gravitational wave event involving a supernova
It confirmed Einstein’s theory of quantum mechanics
It involved the merger of two black holes forming a ~225 solar mass black hole
It was detected using satellite-based observatories for the first time
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: GW231123 was detected by the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA network and involved the heaviest black hole merger recorded, resulting in a ~225 solar mass black hole. This supports Einstein’s General Theory of Relativity and deepens our understanding of black hole formation.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What was the purpose of the Kamaraj Plan introduced in 1963?
options: To industrialize Tamil Nadu after independence
To rebuild the Congress party after the Indo-China war
To introduce land reforms in southern India
To promote education for the backward castes
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: K. Kamaraj was remembered on his birth anniversary (July 15). The Kamaraj Plan, introduced in 1963, aimed to rejuvenate the Indian National Congress after setbacks during the Indo-China war. Senior leaders, including Kamaraj, resigned from official positions to focus on party-building. His contributions to the freedom struggle and democratic strengthening were in focus in recent tributes.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What is the primary objective of the Protection of Civil Rights (PCR) Act, 1955?
options: To protect religious freedom in India
To enforce reservation in public employment
To punish the practice of untouchability
To safeguard minority language rights
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: The Union Government’s 2022 report showed a decline in criminal cases registered under the PCR Act, which was in the news. The PCR Act, formerly the Untouchability (Offences) Act, aims to penalize caste-based discrimination and uphold constitutional civil rights. The recent data highlighted progress in curbing such offenses.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What is the role of the PATRIOT Missile Air Defence System (PMADS), recently sent by the US to Ukraine?
options: Offensive missile attacks on enemy cities
Nuclear deterrence through long-range missiles
Naval missile guidance for submarine warfare
Defense against aircraft, ballistic, and cruise missiles
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: The U.S. decided to send the PATRIOT missile system to Ukraine, making it newsworthy. The system is designed to intercept and destroy aircraft, cruise missiles, and tactical ballistic missiles. It enhances Ukraine’s defense amid ongoing conflict, reflecting deepening U.S. military support in the region.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What makes the LCA Tejas Mark-1A fighter aircraft significant for India's defense capabilities?
options: It is capable of underwater operations
It is India’s first stealth bomber
It is a 4.5 generation multi-role fighter with modern systems
It is a helicopter with AI-based navigation
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: India received the second GE-F404 engine from the U.S. for its LCA Mark-1A project, which brought it into the news. The LCA Mark-1A is India’s advanced indigenous fighter jet with modern systems like AESA radar and electronic warfare suites. It plays a critical role in strengthening India’s air defense and self-reliance in military technology.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: Why is Cabo Delgado in the news, and what environmental concern is associated with it?
options: It is home to Africa’s largest diamond mine
It is the proposed site of four LNG projects threatening climate goals
It declared independence from Mozambique recently
It is the new headquarters for the African Union
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: Cabo Delgado in Mozambique made headlines as four proposed LNG projects there are expected to consume 17% of the world’s remaining carbon budget, according to a recent study. The region is also known for insurgent violence since 2017 and holds ecological and cultural significance, making its development choices controversial.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What is a key directive issued by the Supreme Court regarding the handling of DNA evidence in India?
options: DNA samples must be destroyed after 24 hours
DNA evidence can only be collected with consent from the accused
DNA samples must reach the forensic lab within 48 hours of collection
DNA evidence must be stored only by private agencies
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: The Supreme Court directed that DNA samples collected during investigation must reach forensic labs within 48 hours to preserve their integrity. The directions aim to maintain chain of custody and standardize handling of forensic evidence across states.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What legal provision in the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 supports the use of DNA profiling?
options: Section 17: Right to remain silent
Section 51: Medical inspection of apprehended individuals
Section 73: Criminal surveillance authorization
Section 21: Digital evidence collection guidelines
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: Section 51 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 allows for medical inspection of apprehended individuals, including DNA profiling and other diagnostic procedures as deemed necessary by a registered medical practitioner.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What is the main objective of the ADEETIE scheme launched by the Ministry of Power?
options: To boost tourism in energy-intensive sectors
To provide subsidies to large-scale steel manufacturers
To regulate electricity tariffs in rural areas
To enhance energy efficiency and reduce power consumption in MSMEs
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: The ADEETIE scheme aims to reduce energy consumption by 30–50% in MSMEs, improve the power-to-product ratio, and promote the deployment of energy-efficient technologies in 14 identified sectors.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: Which statement accurately describes the achievements of the Skill India Mission (SIM) since its launch?
options: Only urban youth have been trained under the mission
Women constitute over 70% of the trained population
Over 1.6 crore youths have been trained across 38 sectors since 2015
Skill India Mission only focuses on IT and digital skills
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: Since its launch in 2015, the Skill India Mission has trained over 1.6 crore youths across 38 sectors, with 45% of the beneficiaries being women. It includes schemes like PMKVY, JSS, and PM-NAPS.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What is the role of the Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE) in India’s MSME sector?
options: It provides legal aid to energy companies
It develops energy storage systems for rural households
It implements programs to enhance energy efficiency in MSMEs
It manages import-export of solar panels
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: BEE implements several initiatives to promote energy efficiency in MSMEs, such as the BEE-SME Program, SIDHIEE portal, and the National Programme on Energy Efficiency and Technology Upgradation.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: According to the Sustainable Development Goals Report (SDGR) 2025, what percentage of the global population still lives in extreme poverty?
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: Extreme poverty is defined by the World Bank as living on less than $2.15 per day. According to the SDGR 2025, 8.9% of the global population still lives in extreme poverty, reflecting setbacks caused by recent global crises like the COVID-19 pandemic, climate shocks, and conflicts. SDG Goal 1 aims to eradicate extreme poverty entirely by 2030, but the current trend shows that the world is not on track. Accelerated policy interventions and inclusive economic growth are necessary to address this issue.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What was the recorded global unemployment rate in 2024 as per SDGR 2025?
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: The global unemployment rate reached a record low of 5.0% in 2024, signaling a recovery from disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. This trend is a positive development under SDG Goal 8, which focuses on promoting sustained, inclusive, and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment, and decent work for all. However, the report also notes that youth unemployment and informal employment remain concerns, particularly in developing countries.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: How many children and youth remained out of school in 2023 despite progress since 2015?
options: 272 million
120 million
89 million
310 million
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: As per SDGR 2025, 272 million children and youth were still out of school in 2023, highlighting the gaps in achieving SDG Goal 4 (Quality Education). This includes children in conflict zones, remote areas, or those affected by economic hardships. Though enrollment has increased globally since 2015, challenges like lack of infrastructure, teacher shortages, gender inequality, and digital divide continue to limit access to education in many low-income countries.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: According to the WHO/UNICEF 2024 estimates, by how much did India reduce its number of zero-dose children in 2024?
options: By 43%
By 30%
By 20%
By 50%
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: Zero-dose children are those who have not received even a single dose of routine vaccines. In 2024, India reduced the number of such children by 43%, from 1.6 million in 2023 to 0.9 million. This remarkable improvement in immunization coverage is part of India's progress under SDG Goal 3 (Good Health and Well-being). The success is attributed to enhanced outreach programs, digital tracking systems, and targeted health missions reaching remote and underserved populations.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.questionText: What was a key initiative under India’s Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) to boost measles and rubella vaccination coverage?
options: Ayushman Bharat
Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana
Swasthya Sathi
U-WIN Portal
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 17,.explanation: The U-WIN Portal is a digital platform launched to support the effective implementation of the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) in India. It facilitates real-time tracking of vaccination data, improving transparency and outreach. This initiative, along with campaigns like Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) 5.0, has helped boost coverage of critical vaccines such as those for measles and rubella. These efforts align with SDG Goal 3 and aim to reduce vaccine-preventable diseases and child mortality.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What is the purpose of the Maitri Grants under the Centre for Australia-India Relations?
options: To enhance cultural, educational, and research collaboration
To fund military cooperation between India and Australia
To support bilateral trade in minerals and defense
To promote tourism between the two nations
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: The Maitri Grants, managed by the Centre for Australia-India Relations, aim to foster deeper connections between the two countries in non-commercial domains such as culture, education, and research. These grants help facilitate knowledge exchange, promote mutual understanding, and strengthen long-term bilateral ties.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What makes the Behdienkhlam Festival of Meghalaya culturally significant?
options: It marks the end of the harvest and worships river gods
It celebrates tribal weddings and initiation rituals
It honors matrilineal inheritance systems among the Khasi tribe
It symbolizes the driving away of plagues and evil spirits through bamboo rituals
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: The Behdienkhlam Festival, celebrated by the Pnars (or Jaintias) of Meghalaya in July, is a spiritual cleansing ritual aimed at driving away disease and evil. Young men go from house to house beating roofs with bamboo poles, and traditional games like Dat-lawakor and Iatan-Bhang are played, reflecting both ritual and community bonding.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What is the significance of Exercise Talisman Sabre 2025 for India and global defense cooperation?
options: It is a space mission led by India and Australia
It is a large-scale joint military exercise involving 19 nations, including India
It is a diplomatic summit between Indo-Pacific nations
It is an international trade forum focusing on cyber technology
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: Exercise Talisman Sabre 2025 is a multinational defense exercise hosted in Australia, involving over 35,000 personnel from 19 countries. It includes joint land, air, sea, cyber, and space operations. India’s participation signals its increasing involvement in Indo-Pacific security architecture alongside key partners like the U.S., Japan, and Australia.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What is the function of a Ram Air Turbine (RAT) in aircraft emergency systems?
options: It cools down overheated engine parts
It stores oxygen for cabin pressure maintenance
It generates emergency hydraulic or electrical power when main systems fail
It manages fuel efficiency during long-haul flights
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: A Ram Air Turbine (RAT) is a small turbine deployed during emergencies to provide critical power. It uses the airstream during flight to generate hydraulic or electrical energy, enabling control systems to function even when the main power source is lost. It can be activated manually or automatically based on system design.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What surprising role did a recent study suggest quantum noise might play in quantum systems?
options: Quantum noise can eliminate all computational errors permanently
Quantum noise causes particles to lose mass
Quantum noise improves classical computing speed
Quantum noise may help generate or revive quantum entanglement
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: Contrary to the traditional view that quantum noise only destroys coherence, recent studies suggest it might play a constructive role by reviving or generating quantum entanglement in some scenarios. Quantum entanglement refers to the deeply interconnected state of particles, while noise—typically seen as disruptive—can under certain conditions enable re-entanglement, challenging established assumptions in quantum theory.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What makes the next-generation E10 Shinkansen trains unique in the India-Japan collaboration?
options: They are the fastest underwater trains ever built
They use blockchain to manage passenger data
They deploy crash avoidance systems and are being introduced in both India and Japan
They run on diesel-electric engines for high power
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: The E10 Shinkansen is a next-generation bullet train based on Japan's world-renowned Shinkansen technology. It is being simultaneously introduced in Japan and in India’s 508 km Mumbai-Ahmedabad high-speed rail corridor. Key features include a dedicated track free of level crossings and an ATC (Automatic Train Control) system to prevent crashes, making it among the safest and most reliable transport systems globally.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What does a retail inflation rate of 2.10% in June 2025 indicate for the Indian economy?
options: Sharp increase in prices of luxury goods
Stable food prices and low inflation
High unemployment
India’s GDP fell below 5%
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: Retail inflation hitting a 6-year low at 2.10% in June 2025 signifies price stability, especially in essential goods and services. It is measured by the Consumer Price Index (CPI), which monitors price changes over time in household consumption. A low CPI means inflation is under control, indicating a favorable economic environment for consumers and policymakers.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What legal protections are available to brands like Birkenstock in India against counterfeit goods?
options: Only criminal prosecution under Indian Penal Code
Protection under the Trademarks Act, 1999 and Designs Act, 2000
Compulsory patenting of foreign brands
Mandatory product registration under GST
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: Birkenstock filed a civil suit in India to protect its brand from counterfeit sales. Indian law provides strong safeguards through the Trademarks Act, 1999, and the Designs Act, 2000. These allow companies to take legal action, obtain injunctions, and seize counterfeit products. A 2022 CRISIL study estimated that 25–30% of India’s retail market consists of counterfeit goods, posing risks to consumers and genuine manufacturers.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What is the main role of the National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority (NPPA) in India?
options: To approve new drug trials in India
To manufacture essential medicines for rural areas
To fix and regulate drug prices ensuring affordable access
To import generic drugs from foreign markets
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: The NPPA was established in 1997 under the Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers to regulate the prices of essential medicines. It operates under the provisions of the Drugs Prices Control Order (DPCO). NPPA recently fixed prices for 71 key drug formulations, ensuring affordability and availability of vital medicines across the country.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What recent observation did the Supreme Court make about freedom of speech in the digital age?
options: Citizens should never criticize the government on social media
All social media opinions are protected under Article 370
Only verified users can post opinions online
Freedom of speech requires self-restraint and may be horizontally applied against citizens
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: The Supreme Court emphasized that while freedom of speech is guaranteed under Article 19, its misuse—especially on social media—can lead to societal discord and legal burden. It reiterated the need for citizens’ self-restraint and stated that if self-regulation fails, the state may need to intervene. The Kaushal Kishor case (2023) recognized the horizontal application of fundamental rights, making them enforceable not just against the state but also among private individuals.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What is the main goal behind the Finance Minister's call to boost Global Capability Centres (GCCs) in India?
options: To replace all domestic IT firms with foreign companies
To make India the world’s top coal exporter
To attract Fortune 500 companies that have not yet established GCCs in India
To privatize public banks
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: The Finance Minister emphasized the need for both government and industry to work collaboratively to increase the setup rate of GCCs in India, particularly to attract global Fortune 500 firms. In 2024, India saw an average of one new GCC being established every week, highlighting strong momentum in this sector.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: Which of the following accurately describes Global Capability Centres (GCCs)?
options: They are retail chains owned by multinational companies
They are offshore centers set up by global firms to deliver internal services like IT and R&D
They are offsite centers used solely for international trade negotiations
They are government-run training facilities for skilled workers
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: GCCs, also known as Global In-House Centres (GICs), are offshore service centers set up by multinational companies to handle IT services, research and development, finance, customer support, and more—within the internal structure of their organization. India currently hosts over 1,800 GCCs, making it a global leader in this space.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What is one of the key challenges in the expansion of GCCs in Tier-II and Tier-III cities in India?
options: Limited availability of skilled workforce and infrastructure gaps
Excessive taxation on digital services
Lack of government support for foreign firms
High energy costs due to renewable energy mandates
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: Despite India's GCC leadership, expansion into smaller cities faces barriers like limited availability of skilled manpower and gaps in both physical and digital infrastructure. Regulatory complexity and cybersecurity issues further compound the challenge. Strategic workforce planning and infrastructure investments are key to addressing these issues.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What milestone did India achieve in June 2025 regarding its electricity generation?
options: Installed capacity reached 1,000 GW from thermal energy alone
It became the world's largest exporter of coal-based energy
India reached 50% of its installed electricity capacity from non-fossil fuel sources
It discontinued all nuclear power plants
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: India achieved 50.08% of its total installed electricity capacity (484.82 GW) from non-fossil fuel sources in June 2025—five years ahead of the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) target. This includes renewable energy, large hydro, and nuclear power, positioning India as a global leader in clean energy transition.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: Which initiative has significantly contributed to India's renewable energy expansion?
options: Smart Cities Mission
MUDRA Loan Yojana
Ayushman Bharat Scheme
PM-KUSUM scheme for solar-powered irrigation and PM Surya Ghar for rooftop solar installations
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: PM-KUSUM and PM Surya Ghar are key programs contributing to India's renewable energy growth. PM-KUSUM provides solar-powered pumps to farmers, ensuring energy security in agriculture. PM Surya Ghar promotes rooftop solar installations, with nearly 7 lakh installations to date. These, along with PLI schemes and infrastructure upgrades, have propelled India’s clean energy momentum.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: What are the three key components under the Skill India Programme along with PMKVY 4.0?
options: Skill India Portal, Startup India, and Digital India
PM-NAPS, Jan Shikshan Sansthan (JSS), and PMKVY
Ujjwala Yojana, Mudra Yojana, and Kaushal Bharat
PMKVY, Skill Council of India, and Rural Digital Training Scheme
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: PMKVY 4.0 is a part of the Central Sector Scheme of the Skill India Programme along with two other schemes: PM-NAPS (Pradhan Mantri National Apprenticeship Promotion Scheme), which supports apprentice stipends, and Jan Shikshan Sansthan (JSS), which imparts vocational skills to non-literates and school dropouts. These collectively aim to build a skilled and job-ready workforce.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: Which of the following accurately describes the three training types under PMKVY?
options: Basic Education, Advanced Degree, and Online Classes
Apprenticeship, E-Learning, and On-Job Coaching
Short-Term Training, Recognition of Prior Learning, and Special Projects
Digital Literacy, National Workshops, and Technical Exams
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: PMKVY provides three types of training: Short-Term Training (aligned to NSQF), Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) for certifying existing skills, and Special Projects that provide tailored training for marginalized or future skill sectors. This helps reach diverse learner groups and create a future-ready workforce.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: How has PMKVY contributed to social equity and inclusion?
options: It reduced unemployment in urban metros by 80%
It reserved all courses for economically weaker sections
It excluded tribal regions due to accessibility concerns
It ensured 45% women participation and inclusion of SCs, STs, and OBCs
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: PMKVY has significantly contributed to inclusion by ensuring 45% women participation and by actively involving marginalized communities such as SCs, STs, and OBCs. Initiatives like the PANKH project have focused on skilling women and special training for tribes like the Bru-tribe in Tripura and inmates in Northeast prisons.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: According to the NITI Aayog report, what trade advantage does India gain under the current U.S. tariff regime?
options: India faces a complete ban on steel exports
India has no gains due to highest tariffs globally
India is likely to gain market share in 61% of export value to the U.S.
India loses trade opportunities in textiles due to EU tariffs
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: As per the NITI Aayog report, India is poised to gain market share in 61% of its trade value exports to the U.S., particularly in high-value and labor-intensive sectors. It gains a tariff edge over competitors like China and Mexico in areas such as electronics, steel, vehicles, and textiles.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.questionText: Which policy measures are recommended to boost India’s service trade, as per the NITI Aayog report?
options: Increase excise duty on digital startups
Negotiate service-focused FTAs and expand MRAs
Only focus on AI and ignore traditional service exports
Impose licensing fees on fintech firms
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 16,.explanation: To boost service exports, the NITI Aayog report recommends negotiating service-oriented Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) like the India–UK model, broadening Mutual Recognition Agreements (MRAs) for professional services, simplifying licensing and compliance, and investing in skill development in sectors like digital health, ed-tech, and fintech.

\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 15,.questionText: What makes the newly discovered exoplanet TOI-1846 significant?
options: It orbits our sun and may support human life
It’s the smallest exoplanet found by NASA’s Hubble telescope
It’s a super-Earth orbiting a red dwarf star and may be rich in water
It has the same atmosphere as Venus
\uD83D\uDCC6 Current Affairs – July 15,.explanation: TOI-1846 is a newly found exoplanet discovered using NASA’s TESS data.
